context: Act 2B Chapter 2.2 — Underground international racers arrive. Japanese touge specialists, European circuit pros. Bigger stage.

lines.text: The harbor warehouse has been transformed. What was once a rusted shell is now a staging ground for something unprecedented — an international underground racing event, organized in whispers and encrypted messages, drawing the best illegal racers from three continents.

Cars from worlds you've only read about line the makeshift paddock. A Nissan Silvia with Japanese plates and a turbo setup that defies engineering. A BMW M3 with German racing stripes worn into the paint from actual races on actual mountain passes. A Lancia Delta that looks like it escaped from a rally stage in another century.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Every five years, the underground goes international. Racers from Japan, Europe, South America — they come to whoever holds the strongest scene. For the last decade, that's been Tokyo.

lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: This year, it's us. Because of you. Nova Pacifica's underground hasn't had this kind of reputation since I was racing.
A small group approaches. Three drivers, each carrying the quiet confidence of people who have been the best in their world for a very long time.

lines.speaker: Takumi
lines.text: You are the one they talk about. The champion of Nova Pacifica.
Takumi Hayashi. Japanese touge legend. His reputation precedes him by approximately ten thousand kilometers — the man who has never lost a downhill race on any mountain in Asia.

lines.speaker: Takumi
lines.text: In Japan, we race to understand the road. Not to defeat opponents — to have a conversation with the mountain. I am curious what your roads have to say.

lines.speaker: Katrin
lines.text: Katrin Voss. Berlin. I don't race for philosophy. I race because I'm faster than everyone else.
Katrin Voss. European circuit specialist. Her M3 has won on the Nurburgring Nordschleife in conditions that would make professional drivers refuse to start.

lines.speaker: Santos
lines.text: Luis Santos. São Paulo. I race for the fun. Also the money. Mostly the money.
Luis Santos. South American sprint champion. His smile is infectious and his driving, by all accounts, is terrifying.

choices.text: Welcome to Nova Pacifica. Let's make this a series to remember.
I've been waiting for real competition.
Takumi — I'd like to learn about the touge philosophy.

lines.label: event_format
lines.speaker: Diesel
lines.text: Six races. One on each circuit — Downtown, Harbor, Industrial, Hillside. Plus two night runs. Points accumulate. The top three at the end earn the title of International Underground Champion.

lines.label: katrin_responds
lines.speaker: Katrin
lines.text: Real competition doesn't announce itself. It just shows up and takes your position.
She walks to her M3 without looking back. Challenge accepted. Challenge expected.

lines.label: takumi_teaches
lines.speaker: Takumi
lines.text: The mountain teaches patience. A downhill pass is not about speed — it is about understanding weight transfer, reading the gradient, feeling where the road wants the car to go.

lines.speaker: Takumi
lines.text: In Japan, we say: the fastest driver is the one who listens best. Your mentor — Diesel — he understands this. I can see his teaching in how you drive.
Diesel overhears. His expression doesn't change, but his posture shifts — straighter. Proud.

lines.label: the_stakes
lines.text: The warehouse fills over the next hour. Drivers, mechanics, spectators from the underground communities of a dozen countries. The air hums with languages you don't speak and engine notes you've never heard.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: I've been working on the Sakura all week. New suspension geometry, uprated brakes, a turbo setup that'll compete with anything in that garage.

lines.speaker: Maya
lines.text: These international cars are serious hardware. But I know our roads. And I know our car. That's our advantage.

She is right. The international drivers are talented, but Nova Pacifica's roads are a language they don't speak yet. Home advantage is real — not because of the pavement, but because of the darkness between the corners, the way the harbor mist rolls in at 2 AM, the potholes on the industrial route that will swallow a suspension if you don't know where they are.
Six races. Three continents of talent. The underground has never been this big, and it has never been this dangerous.
You look around the warehouse. Diesel is talking to Koa from the Salts. Takumi is meditating beside his Silvia. Katrin is reviewing data on a laptop. Santos is making someone laugh.
This is the underground at its best — a world within a world, invisible to everyone except those who belong. And you are at its center.
